articles.headline: McCarthy, Bracing for Defections, Eyes a Fraught Path to a Debt Limit Deal
articles.snippet: With right-wing Republicans all but certain to oppose any bipartisan compromise, the speaker has a narrow path to push one through the closely divided House.
articles.abstract: With right-wing Republicans all but certain to oppose any bipartisan compromise, the speaker has a narrow path to push one through the closely divided House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Speaker Kevin McCarthy is attempting a difficult balancing act as he tries to extract spending concessions from President Biden in exchange for raising the debt ceiling: cobbling together a deal that can win the votes of a majority of Republicans without alienating the critical mass of Democrats he would need to push it through the House.
articles.byline: By Catie Edmondson and Luke Broadwater

articles.headline: DeSantis Allies’ $200 Million Plan for Beating Trump
articles.snippet: As the Florida governor prepares to enter the 2024 race, his allies are building an army of organizers to flood the states with the first nominating contests.
articles.abstract: As the Florida governor prepares to enter the 2024 race, his allies are building an army of organizers to flood the states with the first nominating contests.
articles.lead_paragraph: A key political group supporting Ron DeSantis’s presidential run is preparing a $100 million voter-outreach push so big it plans to knock on the door of every possible DeSantis voter at least four times in New Hampshire, Nevada and South Carolina — and five times in the kickoff Iowa caucuses.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Default on U.S. Debt Risks ‘Permanently’ Denting Nation’s Credit Rating
articles.snippet: If the government misses an interest payment, even by a few hours, its creditworthiness will suffer, possibly for a long time.
articles.abstract: If the government misses an interest payment, even by a few hours, its creditworthiness will suffer, possibly for a long time.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the U.S. government defaults on its debt even for just a few hours next week, it could have long-lasting consequences for the nation’s future. Three major ratings companies — S&P Global Ratings, Moody’s and Fitch Ratings — play a big role in how damaging those consequences can be.

articles.headline: Cultural Crackdown in China Shuts Comedy and Music Shows
articles.snippet: Performances across the country were canceled last week after Beijing began investigating a stand-up comedian.
articles.abstract: Performances across the country were canceled last week after Beijing began investigating a stand-up comedian.
articles.lead_paragraph: The cancellations rippled across the country: A Japanese choral band touring China, stand-up comedy shows in several cities, jazz shows in Beijing. In the span of a few days, the performances were among more than a dozen that were abruptly called off — some just minutes before they were supposed to begin — with virtually no explanation.

articles.headline: Driver’s Licenses, Addresses, Photos: Inside How TikTok Shares User Data
articles.snippet: Employees of the Chinese-owned video app have regularly posted user information on a messaging and collaboration tool called Lark, according to internal documents.
articles.abstract: Employees of the Chinese-owned video app have regularly posted user information on a messaging and collaboration tool called Lark, according to internal documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: In August 2021, TikTok received a complaint from a British user, who flagged that a man had been “exposing himself and playing with himself” on a livestream she hosted on the video app. She also described past abuse she had experienced.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Ryan Mac
